evidence: To find its average brightness, or mean, we simply add up all the pixel values and divide by N. This gives us the mean value

triples.evidence: Suppose we have an image X with N pixels. To find its average brightness, or mean, we simply add up all the pixel values and divide by N. This gives us the mean value, which we call mu of X.

evidence: As I mentioned, the Structural Similarity Index is built on three components: luminance, contrast, and structure - or L, C, and S for short.

Once we have the mean, we can also compute the standard deviation. This measures how much the pixel values vary around the mean. Notice that the formula here uses 1 divided by N minus 1, not just N. That detail comes from statistics - it gives us an unbiased estimate of the standard deviation.
